title: Rugby union in South Africa
text:
The Rugby discrimination debate:
It is interesting to compare the current concerns that 'black' players are underrepresented in the Springbok rugby team with the manner the way in which a similar matter developed elsewhere on the planet.
A case in point is the proud history of the New Zealand Maoris, not only in contributing so much to the New Zealand All Black teams, but also as a team that consisted entirely of Maori rugby players, of which the Maori geneology was required to extend back for 25 generations.
The Maori rugby team performed very well in matches against England, Ireland, Wales, Scotland and and Australia from which, in recent times, they have emerged undefeated . A complete listing of the performance of the Maori players on the international stage can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maori_All_Blacks. In 2005 they even beat the British Lions Rugby team. This despite the fact that the Maoris make up only 14.9% of the total New Zealand population of about 4.4 million people.
In view of their success on the international stage it made only common sense that such talented players should be included in the All Black rugby team. Unfortunately some South African politicians have, in their meddling way, either closed or have not considered this avenue of competing as a 'South African black team ', thus honing their skills on the international stage, and instead made "representivity" rather than ability alone, a yardstick for inclusion into a single national South African rugby union team.
There could be many reasons why a black South African rugby union team has not materialised. It could be that, for various historic reasons, soccer has eclipsed rugby as the more popular game played by South Africa's black people.
In that case rugby union could only benefit if it can manage to popularise rugby amongst the country's black population, but one can certainly not dictate to people which sports they should play.
